title: Life With Fibromyalgia: Dealing With the Unbelievers

content: About 5 years before my specialist told me that I had fibromyalgia, I was diagnosed with chronic fatigue syndrome (myalgic encephalomyelitis or ME/CFS). I was 16.

The diagnosis process took well over a year. I came down with some sort of virus that nearly knocked me out of the school musical ( Hello, Dolly! ). In hindsight, maybe I should’ve stayed home. Maybe forcing myself to sing and dance while I was sick was a mistake. Perhaps that contributed to what happened next.

Odd symptoms followed. Parts of my body started to tingle and go numb. Every day the sensation traveled from my toes to my arms, to my fingers to my legs, and back again. Headaches distracted me during class and dizziness forced me to brace myself against the lockers while I walked between classes.
And I felt tired. Bone-tired. Spirit-tired. I struggled to stay awake during class and took a nap almost every day after school.

My parents were very proactive. They took me to specialist after specialist, where I endured test after test. I still remember the nerve conduction test. The little electric shocks didn’t bother me, but the glue from the electrodes got stuck in my hair! That felt like the end of the world to teenage me!

content: One doctor, at a loss, sent me to a therapist. After three sessions, the therapist declared that I was a normal teenage girl.

The diagnosis was a relief after a year of tests that ruled out everything else imaginable. I didn’t have a brain tumor, multiple sclerosis, cancer, or anything else I imagined and dreaded. But there was a name for what I did have: chronic fatigue syndrome.
Naming it felt like a victory. I was a walking smile when I hurried back to school for a rehearsal for the fall play, M*A*S*H (now my favorite TV show!).
A year later, I walked into my AP English class and over to a friend of mine ranting about an episode of The Golden Girls . Why a teenage boy was watching The Golden Girls in 2001, I’ll never know.

content: He’d watched an episode called "Sick and Tired," the first episode of season five (1989). Dorothy (Bea Arthur), the character who felt sick and tired, went from doctor to doctor looking for an explanation.

content: None of the doctors found anything wrong with her. One declared that her symptoms were “all in your head.”

“It’s all in your head” is such a frustrating phrase for those of us who have endured CFS and/or fibromyalgia. It’s the politically correct way of accusing someone of being either insane or a fraud who’s making up the symptoms to get attention.
Poor Dorothy.
In the end, Dorothy was diagnosed with chronic fatigue syndrome. Like me, she felt relieved to have a name for what she was going through.

My friend in AP English, who I remind you was a 17-year-old kid, didn’t like that ending. For several minutes he went on and on about how chronic fatigue syndrome isn’t real and anyone who says they have it is a liar.

17-year-old me told him, “That’s what they diagnosed me with.” I expected him to apologize for his accusations or, at the very least, shut the hell up. But my friend, who heard me perfectly clear, continued his rant until class began.

content: I’ve encountered many unbelievers in the years since. Most are polite. Recently one of my friends said, when I told him I’m living with fibromyalgia, “Oh, is that something they actually diagnose now?”
“Is that actually real?” is what his question implied.

Unlike my friend from high school, this one was innocently ignorant. I meet the ignorant more than the unbelieving. Them, I can easily cope with. Those who refuse to believe that fibromyalgia is real? Those individuals are a struggle.
Especially when that unbeliever is a doctor.
Nobody, not even a doctor, gets to tell me that my pain and fatigue aren’t real. Nobody gets to tell me that it’s “not that bad.”
The bottom line is that it doesn’t matter if someone believes in fibromyalgia or not. I don’t care what they think because their opinions don’t affect what I know to be true.

content: Fibromyalgia is my reality, my “real.” It is “that bad.” It is fact. It is truth.
I live with it. I’ll live with it for the rest of my life. And I’m betting that the unbelievers are fortunate enough to not know what that feels like.
